This is how a friend of mine once described The Economist. This is a newsmagazine par excellence; it is head and shoulders above the rest, and claims (which great justification) to be the newsreporter of the world.
'Since its founding by James Wilson in 1843, The Economist has been the world's most enduring and distinguished proponent of free markest and free trade. 'To be sensible without being heavy, to be lively without being silly, to be original without being eccentric,' as editor Geoffrey Gowther stated 50 years ago, has steadfastly been its mission.'
This magazine is read by the powerful and the power-hope-fuls in every capital in the world. The Economist prides itself on being one edition, consistent in publication throughout the world; it will not succumb to the temptation of 'regional' editions, which might boost sales but lessen the 'one news source for the world'; it also will not do so, that it may tell those governments which threaten it (hoping for a censoring ability) that they must take it or leave it--when various nations have banned The Economist from their shores, it becomes a hot commodity for smugglers!
Until it recently went to regional publications, only once did The Economist make a change; the paper is released on Friday mornings in London, but is already put to print and shipped out for the rest of the world prior to this release. When Margaret Thatcher resigned, the world copies had been issued, but the British printing hadn't been completed. So, they changed the leader. The following week, however, in great integrity, they owned up to the switch, and printed in its entirety the texts of the changed bits.
One source for the world.
In celebration of the 150th anniversary of the magazine, a special book entitled 'The Pursuit of Reason' was released, which includes an exhaustive survey of the history of the magazine, including some very notable contributors (such as English Constitutional commentator Walter Bagehot, whose name still graces the weekly British political commentary). This was a difficult task of reconstruction, considering that the archives of The Economist prior to the 1940s had been destroyed in the London Blitz.
The Economist has a rule of anonymity among authors -- you will find few by-lines on opinions and leaders, and rarely among stories. This helps maintains a sense of 'one voice' for the magazine.
This is a publication with power and clout. The Economist first coined the term 'privatisation' to describe the process of putting a nationalised industry back in private property ownership; the newsmagazine's way of saying this was, however, [a term] 'to describe the returning to profitable private motivation of anything that had declined through unprofitable state intervention--in Europe usually through state ownership, in America usually through excessive regulation.'
When it began 160 years ago, The Economist had a circulation and readership of a little under 2000; now it has nearly a million, with over 80% outside of Britain. This has caused some changes in the magazine. When I worked in Parliament, it was part of my required duties to go to the newsagent each Friday morning and collect copies of the magazine, and spend the morning with one or two MPs reading over the articles. At that time, the sections on Britain and Europe were much more extensive than they are now. The newsmagazine covers America, Asia, Africa, Finance, Industry, Business; it almost always has a special section supplement on an idea (the internet), a particular country (the country reports are required reading for potential investors and diplomats alike), or some such topic.
The Economist has a moderate-conservative social stances, a free-market business and economy bias, and a common sense approach to most issues. It strives to steer clear of social commentary, save when it is of such great import that it is likely to impact on politics or economics. The Economist features short sections for book reviews, science articles, etc., and these are often creative and a little less reigned in by the conventional writers' required standards. But The Economist has maintained a non-affiliation with party politics, rare among British journalists.
'The Economist's radicalism and genuine absence of party loyalty lead to much misunderstanding of its position [of wanting a Conservative victory in 1992, under the banner of 'May the Worst Lot Lose'] particularly because of the often arrogant nature of its criticism and its gift for the wounding phrase. The British press in general is so partisan and so predictable that the concept of an independent organ is a difficult one to grasp.'
The Economist indeed can be haughty and condescending, scathing and arrogant. But, as the opinions will tell you, they have a right to be. They are usually right. This, of course, is the same attitude of Empire that built the Pax Britannia and free trade as a model that survives to this day. Perhaps a little arrogance is not unwarranted, as The Economist has served as the principal organ of record for the free market for 160 years, and shows no signs of slowing.features short sections for book reviews, science articles, etc., and these are often creative and a little less reigned in by the conventional writers' required standards. But The Economist has maintained a non-affiliation with party politics, rare among British journalists.
'The Economist's radicalism and genuine absence of party loyalty lead to much misunderstanding of its position [of wanting a Conservative victory in 1992, under the banner of 'May the Worst Lot Lose'] particularly because of the often arrogant nature of its criticism and its gift for the wounding phrase. The British press in general is so partisan and so predictable that the concept of an independent organ is a difficult one to grasp.'
The Economist indeed can be haughty and condescending, scathing and arrogant. But, as the opinions will tell you, they have a right to be. They are usually right. This, of course, is the same attitude of Empire that built the Pax Britannia and free trade as a model that survives to this day. Perhaps a little arrogance is not unwarranted, as The Economist has served as the principal organ of record for the free market for 160 years, and shows no signs of slowing.

I first started reading The Economist 2 years ago, right after the september 11 attacks. I was attracted to its dramatic cover picture of ground zero, supported by a visionary title: \\"The day the world changed\\". I never missed any issue since then, more and more attracted by the depth of its coverage, the clearness of its analysis, the diversity of topics discussed, and the strange yet appealing mixture of dryness with sense of humour. The newspaper (as it likes to call itself) simply has a sex appeal; Unfortunately, in the recent iraq war, something strange happened to The Economist. It suddenly lost objectivity (in that particular topic) and became very annoying. Don't get me wrong, it has always been provocative (in a good way,) but in iraq, their coverage was becoming ridiculous. It suddenly became preacher in chief for the war, (although i conceed that it did put the most extreme opposition opinions in its letters section), and got transformed suddenly from internationalists to promoters of british interests, complete with sneering at France (they have never admired france anyway). All that has cost them the fifth star that they strongly used to deserve, i hope the economist will revert to its missed self.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14:
Though the \\"best used by date\\" is Nov '03 for the decaf, I am sure the pods will be used up well before then. The coffee taste compares well to the much more expensive (read almost twice as expensive)Illy pods, with a much more pleasing aroma and taste - more nut like - while the Illy has a more traditional espresso dark roast flavor (read burnt - which I am not as fond of, as there is a fine line between dark roasting and ending up burning the beans). The pods produce a nice crema, equal to the Illy. Most of the pods will be used to produce \\"crema coffe\\" and the flavor stands up well to sugar, flavored syrups, and steamed milk. (Crema coffee: Put sweetner in the bottom of your warmed empty cup / mug. Then brew into the cup mug: a double shot 3~4 oz - I brew each shot 25 seconds to draw out the most flavor, aroma. Add 3~4 oz 170 to 180 degree hot water, 3~4 oz steamed milk, and \\"cap\\" with Frothed milk or whipped cream.
I am extremely dissapointed, as of this writing (Late May, 2003) the decaf pods are the only available - been watching the Arabica pods for some time now - \\"coming in soon\\" has been the mantra for the last month. I hope this coffee doesn't disappear, like so many other great offerings here at Amazon - will have to wait and see...
As to the one poor review I have seen here - I suspect the individual who submitted the poor rating does not have his machine set up for pods - different brew head, screen, and brew cup from what is used with ground coffee. If you do not know if there is a brew head for pods available for you machine, contact your dealer / manufacturer - the set up generally runs between thirty and fifty dollars. Although ground coffees can produce a superior cup of espresso - the convenience and the consitency of the brewed cup from pods far outweighs sometimes superior ground / brewed espresso. Highly recommended

column13: The Best Source of World News in the English Language
column14: The Economist is quite simply the very best English language source of international news in print.  Its wide range of articles keep you informed on a multitude of subjects from politics to buisness to the arts and sciences.  It is timley and in-depth, an indespensible tool for any criticaly thinking mind.  Some may complain that its too conservative but that does not negate the fact that if you want to be well informed this is the place to go.  I will never forget my first issue (Mar. 99), given to me by an ardentent marxist professor when I was in college who told me "It may be too conservative for my taste but its still the best source of news availible in English."
This is the best business and current affairs magazine in the world.  Do yourself a favor and start reading it today.

I used to be a loyal subscirber of \\"the economist\\". I recognize the merit that other readers mention below. However in the last days it seems to have become the official propaganda instrument of the Bush administration, like the \\"Pravda\\" of the former Soviet Union, persuading all government and citizen of the world to follow the official truth dictated from washington(otherwise you will have a bad time).I hoped a more critical and unbiased analysis of the war on Iraq, but the magazine was not able to escape from the blinded fanatism that we observe in some of the american and british media that support the war. Actually, what you may find about the conflict on iraq is not different from what you see in the sensasionalist media like fox-news or the national review for example, but at least in these last ones the opinions have signature. column6: Orbit Sugarfree Gum Peppermint, 14-Piece Packs (Pack of 24)
column14: Wrigley's really on to something with this chemical concoction, a testimony to the market-driven forces of progress.  After going through a box in a couple of days, I bought ten shares of the company to give to my son (better than giving him ten cartons of the gum).  At a buck a box, it's a steep price (compared to the twenty-five cent packs), but in exchange you're getting a true designer-label product, the Perrier of chewing gums.  The package is more like an elegant "case," emitting a redolent aroma each time it's opened, followed by a deliriously pungent after-jet of fragrance each time an individually wrapped confectionary treasure is exposed.  As for the morsel itself, it clearly has more staying power than any of its rivals, providing hours of masticating merriment.  But its greatest claim to the consumer's affection for confection is not visual, olfactory or gustatory: it's decidedly tactile.  No gum comes close to this one in the critical areas of texture and viscosity.  The action is positively "springy," guaranteed to put new life in any user's jaw for all of the stressful events of the day.  And at day's end, when the gum's still going strong and you're not, don't be surprised if you suddenly find a use for that neglected bedpost.

column6: El Paso Chile Viva Fajitas Gourmet Food Gift Set

column6: Orbit Sugarfree Gum Peppermint, 14-Piece Packs (Pack of 24)
column13: Be careful what you wish for
column14:
There's no doubt that this gum really works. It contains all kinds of chemicals - the good kind - that make you feel better and give your mouth something to do other than chewing tobacco or mouthing profanities at people (hence its relative popularity among children).
However, last father's day, each of my seven children gave me one of these and ran off before I could give them a thankyou peck on the cheek. I sense that this is the oral hygiene equivalent of being given three crates of deoderant. Something of a mixed blessing.

column13: If you read no other magazine, read this one
column14: If I could pick one of the many magazines to which I subscribe as my only read, it would be this one. This magazine has it all: extensive political coverage and analysis (not just the mainstream stuff that you hear on the networks or read in the daily paper) from all areas of the world. There are areas of literature, technology reports, in depth area reports of different countries, and many other sections, as well as your basic economic stats, graphs and current exchange rates and stuff. The articles are far from stuffy and moreover are written in a witty, tongue in cheek style. I find the style of the Economist to be far more interesting (and daring) than any American periodical that I have encountered. I have also purchased several books from the books review page (they seem to find cool books that I have never seen anywhere else). One drawback? Make time in your schedule to read 100 pages (sometimes more, sometimes less) weekly. I think that it is time well spent. :)

column13: Pro Iraq War, Right Wing, and Conservative
column14:
Very right-wing, conservative, and (what did it in for me) now pro
Iraq war II. A strong bias in favor of anything that makes \\"economic
sense\\" (they are pro drug legalization because of this), but only in
the short term as they do not typically have well thought-out and
long-term visions of the consequences of their positions. They do
speak with an eloquent tongue and therefore have attracted a large
readership base of silicon valley programmers wanting to be
entrepreneurs.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14:
After years of using Starbuck's decaf and regular single serving espresso pods, I finally found a substitute that's more economical and MUCH better tasting.
I've used three different brands of pods in my Starbuck's Barista machine, and have found that the quality of the pod and the flavor of the espresso inside is, by far, the best in the Espressione pods. The flavor is more full bodied and stronger than in the Starbuck's pods. I actually use one pod to make two shots of espresso, and the flavor is more intense than when I buy my specialty drinks from Starbucks or other coffee houses.
Also, the pod itself is of very high quality. Each pod is individually wrapped in an airtight, hard foil wrapper, and I've never opened a package yet that contained a torn pod with coffee spilling out. Such is not the case with other lesser brands.
The tab on each pod is also handy, making it easier to switch out a hot spent pod with a new one when making a second round of espresso.

column13: Keeps you abreast of the WORLD!
column14:
The Economist is quite simply one of the best magazines published today. It's timely commentary, witty with a strong dose of common sense, allows the reader to stay informed of major (and sometimes minor) happenings around the globe. The magazine is hardly about economics but rather the reader will gain valuable insights into world politics, world business, economics, technology, and even social issues. From time to time, they publish a "survey" (an in-depth look) of a nation or an issue.
I greatly admire the non-condescending tone of the magazine. When they state the name of company (even extremely popular global firms), they almost always add what type of firm it is (i.e. bank, consultancy, etc.).
Furthermore, as someone who lives in the U.S., it is informative to learn about non-U.S. points of view on American policies (The Economist is mainly centered from England). The Economist is extremely valuable as it is informative.

column13: Get a balanced view of the world
column14: The economist is not specifically about economics - it is instead a great balanced view of the world.  The journalists actually check their facts - and make some intriguing incisive points that often are not the politically correct trash that you read in other news magazines.  If you are interested in the world then you should read this magazine.

column13: Don't Listen To The Negative Review
column14:
It seems like right now Amazon is getting rid of El Paso drink sets so they've dropped the price of the whole line. I've tried a couple of these El Paso gift sets at the vastly reduced prices for presents. I like them so much I kept one of each for entertaining. The martini has the lowest rating on Amazon and only one review. The others are highly rated. I can't figure why the martini set does not have more positive feedback. It's my favorite.
The music CD has some great cocktail standards and some less obvious selections to keep it interesting. I like the olive design of the glass picks. The cocktail olives and onions are pretty typical and come in matching bottles. The drink guide is silly but might be useful to a novice mixologist. Likely your drunken guests will just look at the pictures!
At the list price this is your typical gift set markup ripoff but at the reduced price you could not buy the raw materials in a market let alone add on a swing mix CD.
I gave it five stars to offset the two star review and because at the reduced price you really CAN'T go wrong. At full price I might give it two stars too.
Cheers.

column13: The Economist is worth every cent
column14:
The Economist is the best weekly publication I've have ever read. It is concise, witty, hilarious (honestly, at times I've bursted laughing at their sarcasm), and open-minded. It's amazing that a magazine can cover so much and say so much in about 90 pages week in and week out. For a British publication, they cover a lot of the US. I heavily rely on it to get my news and analyses. And I would say that it is perhaps the only reliable news publication (yes, a big statement). In fact, I cancelled my subscription to Business Week in favor of the Economist.
They are also not afraid to tackle difficult subjects like the Israel, race relations, corruption, etc. They give credit where credit is due, and are quick dish out blame as well. No one escapes unscathed.
I add that I don't agree with all their views (like when they advocated for Clinton to 'Just go' or when they made the case to legalize drugs), however I feel that there is a little bit of everything for everyone in the magazine. And even if they say something that turns your stomach, at least you'll have something to discuss or be outraged.
The best features of this magazine are their technology reports (released quarterly), industry and country surveys, and year-end Christmas, special issue.
The magazine is expensive when compared to Time or Newsweek. But the analyses and news coverage you get is certainly worth it. To those that complain about the price, I say you get what you pay for.

This is an exceptionally well-written magazine, and always an entertaining read. It has an air of authority based on the obvious depth of its information but there are occasional unexpected touches of humour too. Good for flights!

column13: Possibly the best-written newsmagazine in English
column14:
I have read The Economist for over 15 years now. I rely on it not only for news but also for thoughtful commentary on world events. Even if you don't agree with its point of view (and it does have one, a very free-trade oriented, classical liberal, free market viewpoint), it will make you think. The reporting and the writing are aimed a bit higher than the average newsmagazine, making it a more interesting and thus enjoyable read.
The Economist reports the news from around the world, including parts of the world most Americas are not aware of. It is divided into sections: US, UK, Europe, Americas, Asia and "rest of the world," as well as Business, Finance and Science/Culture/Sport. Reading this magazine regularly allows me to stay on top of the main issues in the US and abroad in a very effective way.

This is definitely a game to look at. I've been looking at other platformers and I know that this one is going to be missed be some of the other games out there, but I hope this helps you at least find out what this game is all about.
I've been playing this game for about 15 hours and I'm still finishing the third world. I found it hilarious in some cases, and frustrating at times, but over all it's a very fun game. I love the look of the levels and characters.
It gets better and better. It's targeted for the gamer in mind. You won't finish it in a few hours that's for sure.
"Quote from a reviewer:
The sheer amount of platform games this holiday season is truly uncanny. With the likes of Sly Cooper, Mario, Ratchet and Clank, and Blinx the platform fans are sure to have their fills this x-mas. Midway has decided to join the action with it's quirky title Dr. Muto. A bizarre game about a mad scientist that can morph into creatures after compiling their DNA structure. While this is a truly unique concept, not not original, can this game survive amongst the larger and more widely known characters fighting for your platforming buck? The answer is a resounding yes and even in some way Muto exceeds their efforts. Let's take a look at another perfect example of an underground hit shall we?
Graphics
Visually this game is beautiful, large environments sporting some of the most unique architecture this side of Tim Burton. Very organic in it's look and design Muto's worlds are chock full of amazingly animated enemies and colorful hazards such as toxic sludge. The frame rate is as smooth as ice and the animations are flawless. From Muto's outrageous victory dances to the enemies scattering when being trapped this game has style to match it's unique look and feel. The only downsides are a lack of super textures, the ones here are damn good but could be better, and some nice XBox touches like reflections and bump mapping. All in all an absolutely gorgeous game.
Sound
Having memorable music is a must in a platform game, you can still hear the Mario theme in your head can you not? Dr. Muto comes across pretty standard in the department. With some typical techno beats mixed with peculiar sound effects the fare seems to drive the game forward, yet it fails to excel or leave anything for you to hum along with. The sound effects on the other hand are top notch, creepy sounds of cockroaches, putrid sounds of liquid and waste, mixed with some excellent voice acting add to the strange personality this game portrays. Dr. Muto himself muttering his "sometimes" understandable lingo to Al your personal computer with his monotone jokes about how the current situation is suitable for a videogame but not a mad scientist are of the highest quality.
Gameplay
This is where the game draws you in and doesn't let go. You are in control of Dr. Muto, a mad scientist with the ability to morph into creatures to accomplish goals. Sounds like a simple concept but the best part is the game does it so well by teaching you only what you need to know thus perfecting your skills for the later levels. You use the X button to perform what is called trapping, by trapping so many of the same creature you are given the ability to morph into it. This adds depth and personality and requires you to learn each function continuing to add more game for your buck. The game also switches styles on you from time to time adding challenge and variety, the screen often flips to the side for some old school 2D side scrolling action. Making jumps and timing are key to these challenges and continue to excel this game further in this department. While easy to pick up and taking a good amount of time to master Muto has certainly been designed with gamers in mind!
Overall
What this game does it does well and that is deliver a truly unique and fun experience for gamers. If you are a fan of platforming games and are tired of the same old crap then definitely pick this masterpiece up. It will deliver to you many hours of gaming goodness on top of being just downright entertaining to play. Watching this game is almost as fun as playing it and that is a feat less and less achieved in the gaming realm these days. I suggest giving this sleeper a rent, it may mutate your thoughts on platforming games in general. Highly recommended!

The Economist is a good magazine but the proscriptions it gives are based on linear, steady-state economics--and in the long run we are all dead. It gives short term gamesmanship and chaotic theory short shrift (somebody once noted most corporations in the long run go bankrupt, so the short-term is very important for an economy). As such, it tends to get a bit boring and predictable.
Also, as a minor quibble, it is much more liberal (modern sense) and less anti-statist and doom and gloom than it was a while ago, as another poster noted. I prefer a liberarian, no-government advocacy in op-eds, but that is just an advocacy position, which reasonable people can quibble over.
However, all in all, the Economist is good, only because of the poor competition. And it has great stories if you are international in scope.

The Economist has consistently been the best international political and economic journal. The strength of its research, analysis and journalism is superb. The presentation is crisp, clean and doesn't ever distract from the content. The magazine usually far surpasses its rivals. Highly Recommended.

In order to keep abreast of current affairs throughout the world, one can do no better than read "The Economist". Quite simply, this magazine has no competitors that come close in terms of coverage or quality.
Although I have been a subscriber for some 20 years, I never cease to be excited about opening a new week's edition. "The Economist" provides an insightful and analytical view of the news and never fails to provoke one's mind.
Read it!

column13: You won't necessarily agree with it, but you have to read it
column14:
Yes, the Economist puts forth views that would be abhorred by protesters at WTO meetings. However, that's part of why you need to read it. This is a magazine that's read by some of the most powerful people in the world. ...
If you want to understand what the economic and political elite thinks and why, you must read the Economist, cover to cover, every week.
It won't be a chore either. The Economist is well written--\\"witty\\", as other reviewers have said. The articles in a given week will generally have a nice range (aside from America and Britain, the editors try not to make one country appear every week in the news section unless it's crucial). The writers and editors are generally upfront about their views: news articles, as well as the leaders (editorials to Americans) are forthright and opinionated. This is neither the bland \\"news\\" of Time nor the dense prose of an academic journal. It's a news magazine meant for the busy, intelligent professional who needs to know things and has the mental capacity ro process complex issues, but has neither the time nor the patience to wade through endless seas of paper. ...

column13: The Preeminent Newsmagazine of the World
column14:
The Economist is the most superior newspaper in the world. Although it is in a magazine format, it's own editors refer to it as a newspaper, and it may be better understood in that context. Here are a few reasons why it is so superior:
- There are no bylines, on any articles. The Economist maintains the belief that \\"what is written is more important than who wrote it.\\" This removes opportunities for vanity reporting and grandstanding by authors with agendas.
- It's charter prohibits majority ownership by any one particular media group, further cutting down on bias.
- Everything written in the magazine must withstand the test of fact. As such, rumour, conjecture, or any other tabloid type news is not found within it's pages. As such, it may not break open too many new stories, but you'll certainly never risk embarrasment by saying, \\"well, as I was reading in the Economist...\\"
- I've heard, though not verified, that only two news publication can be quoted for doctoral theses in Ivy league schools. Those are the Christian Science Monitor and the Economist.
With a framework like that, you know you are going to be spared the tabloidism of the broadcast media, the \\"lifestyle management\\" of the \\"lite\\" newsmagazines, and be treated to the most thorough and factual analysis of important issues anywhere. The Economist is one of the few last bastions of JOURNALISM left. Most so-called \\"news\\" media is really broadcasting, rather than journalism, and as such is more concerned with selling product rather than reporting events.
As to concerns with bias, yes the Economist has it's biases, just like any magazine. However, to attempt to characterize it as \\"liberal\\" or \\"conservative\\" does not make sense in the context of the Economist. A magazine that is pro-gay rights, pro-euthanasia, and anti-capital punishment, yet at the same time, highly pro-trade, free market and very pro-defense, defies characterization in any one direction. While you may disagree with it on certain stances, at least you will never wonder how they reached their conclusion.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14:
Something odd must have happened to Mr. Kelly.
I have compared the espressione pods with those made by Illy, Starbucks, Saeco, and another I've forgotten, and the espressione pods produce the best espresso with the strongest taste of any.

This magazine is absolutely amazing. The Economist was first suggested to me during a lecture my freshman year in college. The lecturer was speaking about Supply Chain Management, but he stopped the lecture 10 minutes early and began passionately speaking about The Economist. It was the passion in his voice that convinced me to try it out. \\"How good could it possibly be?\\"
Admittedly, it took me a while to get into it. It is very dense, and if you haven't ever really studied world issues, you'll have some catching up to do. But within 6 months, I was hooked. I've been (obsessively) reading it now for 3 years, and it has truly changed my life. Besides giving me a huge advantage over my peers in business (undergrad) school, and helping me maintain my 3.986 cumulative GPA with 2 majors and 2 minors, it has changed the direction of my life. I'm now studying abroad in Hong Kong, and I plan to work in Latin America and then later in Asia.
But, I would suggest this to anyone, whether or not they are in business. The Economist has a network of reporters all over the world. It is very well written and it covers a broad range of issues/disciplines/geographical areas. Unlike most Western media sources, it provides deserved coverage of Africa and Asia. It is also extremely progressive (and arguably liberal, despite what its critics may say).
While reading the magazine, I have been approached by people on subways and in cafes. \\"You read The Economist? Isn't it great!?\\" People who read it know.
Read The Economist for 3-6 months... give it that long. You won't be disappointed. And if you're reading some [stuff]like \\"Newsweek,\\" burn it. The Economist is the way to go.

If you want to stay informed about what is happening in the world, you have to read the Economist every week - which is no easy task because it manages to pack an enormous amount of good reading between its covers every 7 days.
Unlike several other magazines, the Economist has a truly global coverage - not just an American or a European perspective. Asia, Africa, Europe, USA, South America - in politics, economics, science, arts - if its happening, the Economist will probably have something to say about it.
You might not always agree with it, but you have to admire its analytical depth and perspective.

column13: man, it is a very good magazine
column14:
I dont need to say much, since other people have basically said it all, but I want to add that its special surveys rock.
Although its a quite right-wing magazine, and it sometimes says stuff that i disagree, its logic and reasons are relevant, which makes its opinions quite useful. However, I also rely heavily on a Chinese magazine thats more like a left-wing magazine to get another perspective.
This is a magazine for people who believe that \\"knowledge is power\\", by reading this magazine, you get an in depth view of the world, thus you can predict the future and make the best/most out of it. Get it now, and you will be one step ahead of the other people. (How come I feel I am doing a commercial for The Economists.....)
Oh well, I guess I better say something bad about it too, ITS SOOOOOOO EXPENSIVE compares to other news stuff, but hey, greatness requires sacrifice, right?

Why people persist in reading Newsweek and Time is beyond me. For one, the quality of reporting is only a few steps above that of a supermarket tabloid. They are trite, superficial and sensationalistic. Both were once vital reading, but no longer.
The Economist has a very different editorial mission--and a bit of an axe to grind (free markets) which it is very up front about. It is able to distill the significant world events into a weekly format without loss of quality while providing superior analysis.
Critics have complained that The Economist does little true original reporting, relying on news that has already hit television and newspapers around the world. True enough, yet there is no other publication that gives you the world as succinctly and intelligently as The Economist.
Now if it weren't so bloody expensive.

By this time,you probably are aware that this magazine is more than just about economics.
I read a sample issue,subscribed and I am hooked to it ever since.
Witty,incisive and many a times,politically incorrect but factual summaries on the main issues plaguing the world.
The fact that it is British is reflected in the many stories and ads concerning Britain and Europe.But the wit is well worth it and anyway far more tolerable than the garbage that goes in other magazines.Recommended reading for Americans who are bombarded with needless stories on TV and other media.

I am a HUGE lover of Frango's Mint Chocolates and a HUGE lover of ALL things Caramel. I figured, "How can I go wrong"? Well ... I was a little disappointed in the flavor of the Frango Caramels. The caramel filling itself had a slightly stale flavor to it and the filling didn't compliment the chocolate shell the same way the velvety Mint filling does.

I will say this ... Target did an AMAZING job of packing these chocolates and shipping them quickly. They came with an ice pack and were sealed inside a foam container inside the shipping box. ORDER CHOCOLATES FROM TARGET.COM WITH CONFIDENCE! (just stick to the plain Mint) :-)

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column13: Old World Taste-Comfort of Your Own Home
column14:
I've tried the ESPRESSIONE coffee pods in both the 100% Arabica blend and also the Espresso blend. They are sensational.
Taste is excellent along with the AROMA.
The pods are also much less expensive that we can find in stores and on line from other roasters.

I've been reading The Economist for the last 10 years or so, and during that time the magazine has earned my utmost respect in every sense. I just wish I had heeded their advice concerning the stock market bubble back in the late 90s.

The Economist is certainly the best of the weekly newsmagazine genre but it is not quite perfect. Back in my college days, I once heard that there was the Economist and then there was Slime, Newspeak and Useless News and World Distort. I won't disagree. Its not perfect since, occasionally, the other American newsmagazines will cover some US stories in more detail than will the Economist but then you have to wade through umpteen pointless human interest stories or even stupider stories on celebrities.
Over the past 20+ years, roughly how long I've been reading the Economist, its editorial slant has gone from Far Right to Right of Center (assuming that old fashioned Liberals are considered center-right) on economic/financial matters and Left of Center on social issues. It is very difficult to exactly categorize the publication since it is usually too intelligent to slavishly toe any line other than one of abhorring waste and stupidity.
If you are trying to 'pin' it down, the slant of the Economist is in favor of 'market based' solutions to virtually any problem that can be analyzed in those terms:
Trade? For it! What about displaced workers? Retrain them! What if they are too old or too ill-educated to be retrained? Would be better to buy 'em off with a lump-sum payment! Net, all of society will still be better off!
Pollution? Against it! BUT use the market mechanism to reduce it at the lowest cost in terms of jobs lost or firms forced out of business.
Abortion? Pro-choice since it is in favor of maximizing individual choice and responsibilities (the sine qua non of any market society).
I think you get the idea. The particular strength of the Economist is its ability to explain very complex, abstract economic theory in terms any intelligent layman can understand. (Note: I do NOT say, "any person" as there are far too many stupid people out there who cannot understand anything, no matter how hard you try to explain it). The Economist is the best all-round news weekly available but falls behind the Far Eastern Economic Review if that part of the world is what you are interested in. Short of that, buy it.

An addendum to my previous review :
Oftentimes inside the magazine there will be special offers that have subscriptions at greatly reduced prices. It's worth picking an issue up and seeing what's on offer before clicking here.

column13: My favorite news magazine by far
column14:
The Economist rarely disappoints. Unlike the fluff that fills the pages of Time, USNWR, and Newsweek, the Economist covers news that's fit to print, not just what will sell magazines (i.e. no celebrity photos, no \\"God Bless America\\" patriotism, no health-news infotainment, and no avalanche of advertising that falls out of the magazine when you pick it up.). Unlike Business Week and other business news sources, the Economist isn't into stock picking, cheesy management books, hot sectors, and celebrity investors. The Economist is about facts, about reporters doing real research, and about consistent excellence.
Time, Newsweek, and friends may have their place in the dentist's waiting room, but when I want to know what's going on in the world, or gather facts to make an opinion, the Economist is the first news source at hand.
The Economist has
* detailed news on events all over the globe
* heads of state, nobel prize winners, company leaders, and informed citizens' opinions on the letters page
* long surveys of difficult problems (corporate finance problems, Chinese political reform, open source software)
* real criticism on policies and plans
* accessible ways to understand complex concepts (i.e. explaining purchasing-power parity by comparing the prices of Big Macs in various countries)
* remarkably fresh language for such a serious news source
I've been reading it for years, starting from high school debate, college libraries, and borrowing copies from friends. After graduating, I bought it from newstands for a year, and a few months back I gave in and got a three year subscription. It's expensive, but I'm sure it's money well spent.
Besides saving money by subscribing, print subscriptions often include online access, as well. I haven't used it yet, but I imagine the searchable archives are excellent for research.

column13: Excellent writing from a corporate globalist perspective
column14:
Unlike most of the reviewers, I noticed a stong bias in the coverage of the magazine. The writing is clever and well done, and the breadth of issues covered is quite wide. They are not writing for dummies, which does make it more enjoyable to read than most weeklies. For that reason, as well as the fact that I majored in Economics in college, I subscribed for a year.
I enjoyed the 'unbiased' reporting for a few months and then picked up on a quite strong bias actually. While not being partisan for any political party, it is quite partisan in its 'cosmopolitanism', i.e. it is very pro global business. Fair enough, by examining the advertisements in the magazine, global business pays a lot of the magazine's bills. My populist sentiments from a Midwestern upbringing led me to stop my subscription.
Shortly afterwards, I became aware of informal global business powwows, like the Trilateral Commission and Bilderberg. Often, political leaders are invited to these conferences, as well as central bankers, media figures, NGO leaders as well as business leaders. They meet once a year, similar to the G-8 meetings. Anyhow, editors from the Economist are often rapporteurs at these meetings that get almost no coverage in mainstream media. I recalled the Economist calling Ian Duncan Smith(current leader of the Conservative party in Britain) akin with Atilla the Hun. Why? He is(or was) opposed to Britain joining the European Union and wants to keep the Pound. Who did they support to take over the reins of the Conservative Party? Kenneth Clark, Bilderberg participant. When the race for the Conservative Party leadership ended up between these two, and Smith looked like the probable winner, I remember the 'unbiased' Economist suggesting that the Conservative Party might be buying a one-way ticket to the political wilderness if the Conservative Party becomes anti-Europe(pro-Smith), while Labor would become the new center-right party. If our political process reflected the will of the people(which it doesn't), this statement by the Economist would have been ludicrous.
The Economist propogates the views of a coterie of central bankers, financiers, and industrialists with a pro-globalism viewpoint. Not all financiers and industrialists are part of this coterie, Burlusconi for example, but the political goals and institutions of this coterie escape critical analysis. Fair enough, if they want to propagate their views, that is their own business, but objective it ain't.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14: Using the Briel Chamonix machine I purchased from Amazon, I have produced delicious lattes using these pods. The smell of the Espressione pods (regular and decaf) when opened is incredible - dark, rich roasts.  FYI - the pods are produced in Italy, which is a good sign.  Also, each pod has a handy paper \\"tab\\" so that you can remove it from your machine without burning your fingers.  I compared these pods to Starbucks espresso pods (regular and decaf), and the Espressione are my favorite.  Only one warning:  150 pods (individually wrapped) take up a lot of space, so be sure you know where you're going to store them.  More good news:  each box of 150 is stamped with a \\"best if used by\\" date, which in my case was 16 months after the date of purchase.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14: I am an experienced espresso and cappuccino maker.  I purchased the l'espresso pods because of the reviews on Amazon.  Contrary to the other reviews, I found these pods produce a cappuccino without any significant taste,weak and shockingly bland. I have an expensive machine which typically makes wonderful cappuccino and espresso with various species of coffe which I grind myself.  The absence of taste in these pods was deeply disappointing and I would urge experienced cappuccino drinkers to avoid them.

column13: A Good Read for an American
column14: Provides excellent, even handed exposure and analysis to global issues and politics.  This is an important news magazine for Americans to read, no left or right lean at all.  The Economist provides a viewpoint that no other magazine readily available in the US can offer.  The only one I have ever read that is interesting cover to cover.

I subscribe to several magazines, including an American news magazine, but by far, The Economist is superior in every way. The reporting is free from the glitz and glamour found in more popular American publications and serves its readers a mix of international and economic coverage that is unsurpassed in the mainstream print media.

column13: Don't let the name fool you
column14:
Despite the name, The Economist is not a magazine about economics. It offers a full range of coverage about politics, world affairs, business, books, arts, culture... and of course, finance and economics. As an American, I especially appreciate the Economist's outsider perspective on U.S. issues; it puts all the silly things that the American media focus on in a more balanced perspective. Of particular note, the weekly "Lexington" column offers perhaps the most insightful commentary on U.S. politics of any newspaper or magazine, and it does it with prose that is witty and direct.
Many people complain about the price, but let me tell you: it is worth every penny. I started a subscription on a lark several years ago and thought I would not renew it when it expired, but I became addicted. It is the only magazine I read. I eagerly await the mailman's arrival every Saturday afternoon, because I know he'll be bringing me the best and most comprehensive news and analysis magazine in this world.
One minor criticism: if you live in parts of the country that are away from postal hubs, you may not get your magazine on Saturday like you are supposed to. When I lived in Hawaii, it was always several days late -- and this was maddening. Even in the Washington DC area, I sometimes wouldn't get my copy until Monday. But ever since they started printing the U.S. edition of the magazine in California, it has gotten somewhat better.

As an Economist reader since College days, I remain impressed with the high level of writing and coverage of world events as well as scientific and cultiral maaters. COverage of North AMerica has improved too. Not simply opinionated, the Economist presents all the reasons underlying their opinions enabling the reader to agree or disagree based on facts. Oddly enough for a weekly based on the "dismal science", every issue has moments of wit and outright humor.

I have been an avid reader of this magazine for a few years now. I have previously subscribed to Time and Newsweek. The Economist is by far the one with the most depth in international issues. I would especially recommend their quarterly technology reviews that enable their readers to see what technology will be making impact in their personal and professional future
It is a must for anyone interested in getting objective international news coverage.

column13: The Best Magazine in the World
column14:
I have no doubt in my mind that the Economist is the best magazine in the world. It provides the most objective, fair, complete and factual view of the world that I have ever come across in the Media (Mainline US Media is a shame to US democratic values with its blatant biases.)
The articles in this magazine are concise and to the point, unlike lengthy rumblings in the magazines like Newsweek and Time. If I had just one magazine in the world, "The Economist" would be the one I will choose.

What other sentiments can I add that other reviewers have not already expressed? Well, for one, I have been reading The Economist for the past twenty years. Looking back, I believe I have missed only one issue in that entire time. Reading it has become indepensible. Indeed, my weekend does not really commence until I have strolled home with the week's edition of The Economist in hand.
Through wars, market corrections and the occasional political scandal, The Economist has always provided a critical filter to make sense of what has transpired. In an ever changing world its unique form of journalism is the one constant I can count on. I know it will fairly and succintly present the major issues of the day; oftentimes too with a wit and verve one would not expect from a newspaper that bills itself as a "specialist publication."
So, do not let its dry title fool you. The Economist is a paragon of journalism for everyman. An inquiring mind is all one needs to appreciate its merits!

Like most Americans, I used to depend on MTV News and the monologues from Jay Leno and Letterman to get my news. The information presented in this news magazine is so much better. At first I was wary of the business-centered title and the UK-centric writing. However, it is an incredibly well-rounded magazine covering world politics, business, and a little technology and culture. The British slant is obvious, but there is actually more coverage of the USA and its individual states than anything else. The authors are nameless, but I suspect some writers are clearly Americans by the evident conservative and pro-Bush tone that's so fashionable these days. There is dry humour evident throughout the magazine; occasionally it is a bit inappropriate (in January the subtitle for a photo showing a demolished Afghan city was \\"in need of some refurbishment.\\")
The writing style is incredible and one which I would like to follow myself in my own writing. Each article presents a clear opinion on the matter at hand, but the author always presents both sides of the issue in a logical manner. The information is presented with a strict just-the-facts manner. If you want to cut through the [junk], read this magazine. The technology and science articles are suprisingly well-written as well. I can't recommend this rag enough. The only qualm I have is that it's rather expensive, but this is the price you pay for having a magazine that's not filled with mainstream advertisments.
This is the most enlightening publication out there.  Excellent coverage of the condition of the world every week.

I don't have an interest in business, but I subscribe because it is the only newsmagazine regularly published which really has worldwide coverage. Terrific articles, well written, to the point, and 4 pages a week on each region of the globe.
Skip all the Britney Spears stories in Time and Newsweek, and subscribe to the Economist.

If magazines were like women, which would clearly make for an interesting subscription dynamic, then The Economist would be the supermodel without peers.
My first exposure to The Economist was a brash little hand out, where the newspaper(it doesn't like being called a magazine, tut tut) said that it was required reading on Downing Street and Wall Street. I was a little suprised with the puffery, but curious enough to see if this little British rag could live up to its own hype.
Could it ever. It's the one thing in the world -- sorry New York Times, sorry Wall Street Journal, and I just feel bad for you, USA TODAY -- that can keep you fully aware of global events every week. And not just aware of Europe. Not just aware of British politics. And not just aware of remarkably cogent issues concerning American politics. But knowledgeable about a potential Caribbean stock exchange, Robert Mugabe's worthless leadership in Zimbabwe, and more.
When I spent a few months messin around with Eastern Europe, I missed my plane out of Prague, just so I could go back and grab my copy of that week's Economist. I figured, how could I live without it?
The thing is, if you care about the world, you can't. Advertising Age said it best -- "Even those who toil in journalism are awed by The Economist." Would that such a supermodel existed.

I have been reading The Economist since 1973 (my father subscribed) and have never found a better source for informative and insightful reporting on the world at large. There was a sharp editorial turn to the right in 1978, but it's been ameliorated lately to the more traditional dispassionate (but cutting) neutrality. Changes in format and style have been more frequent in the recent 5 years (which I have not always endorsed - I'm still not pleased about their switch to color, as I think the black & white forced them to be more trenchant in their illustrations), but where else could one go to find out the political machinations of remote corners of the earth that American magazines never heard of?
It may be hard going to read at first, especially if you're accustomed to the "look boys and girls, today we're going to visit the White House. Oooh, is that the President we see? Has he been naughty or nice?" tone of Time and Newsweek. Stick with it - you'll never go back. Sometimes the American reporting has appeared to analyze everything according to its effect in Washington DC, but this too shall pass.
The business reporting is spectacular, and there are nuggets throughout each issue in various areas including the frequently oddball statistics in the Economic Indicators section. Never miss the Letters section: I recall brutal and searing exchanges between Henry Kissinger and William Shawcross when his book on the bombing of Cambodia was reviewed, as just one example.
There is no finer magazine since the demise of Ross's New Yorker. Subscribe and enjoy.

column13: Best Source for News Analysis - Period.
column14: Though I'm just echoing what many have already mentioned in the reviews before me, I can not emphasize enough how different this publication is compared to the likes of Newsweek and Times.  Please do not be mislead by the magazines title 'The Economist.' While it covers business and the economy in detail it offers so much more, including a detailed analysis of all the major news stories from around the world.The magazine is published weekly in sections which cover all the geographic areas (for in depth news analysis -  and not just when there is a war going on there), Business and Finance, and Arts amongst others.  One of my favorite sections is the one page obituary they always devote to someone of distinction (not necessarily the most famous) every week.The writing is always concise (and always without a byline) and a certain dry humor permeates the magazine throughout.  Sometimes the amount of information contained in the weekly can be a bit overwhelming, but it is always presented in a very clear manner.  The analysis is always well thought out and well researched and typically, the Economist, will not shy away from giving its own opinions.  This is the sort of magazine that you may not always agree with, but one which you will always respect.

column13: Outstanding News and Analysis -- In Great Quantities
column14:
The Economist's reputation for insightful and expert reporting generally overshadows a wonderfully pointed humor that is rarely petty. Moreover, the writing is possessed of much greater confidence than is the norm in the press. A recent article on Enron has a nice example of both, it noted:
"In August 2001, an Enron employee, Sherron Watkins, had written to her boss, Kenneth Lay, expressing her concern that \\"we will implode in a wave of accounting scandals.\\" If Ms Watkins, whose field was \\"corporate development\\", could see the writing on the wall, surely Andersen should have been able to read it."
Much of the press seems to have no instinct for when to hedge about what allegedly may be true and when to draw sensible conclusions and address the consequences. This inability is the chief cause for the shallow coverage of which many of us are tiring. The Economist, on the other hand, has an almost unerring sense in this regard and it is very refreshing.
One note of warning . . . The Economist is the finest monthly newsmagazine currently being published. The only problem is that it comes out once a week. It is tough to keep up.

column13: Excellent Coverage of Economics, Politics, & World Events
column14:
Echoing the comments of many previous reviewers, The Economist provides the best balanced, analytical coverage of current events in all of journalism. The only magazine comparable in the U.S. is U.S. News & World Report and The Economist provides a more detailed and worldly perspective. If you are an IR/ Econ/ Political Science student or professor, you should subscribe to this magazine. It's weekly arrival is all you need to satisfy a thirst for more than a superficial coverage of world events received from watching 30 minutes of CNN. As a former economics instructor, I frequently referred to The Economist for timely, balanced, in-depth coverage of political and economic events throughout the world, including the U.S. & the Americas, Europe, Asia, and the other major regions of the globe.
If you manage a tight budget, as many college students do, you can subscribe online to the economist.com and receive a fair amount of material for free. If you subscribe online, the economist.com charges $59 annually (about half of what a print subscription costs). Registration is free on their website, and subscribers can receive weekly emails of \\"This Week in Politics\\" and \\"This Week in Economics\\" for free, as well. Readers can also sign up for \\"The Global Agenda\\" which arrives three times per week and highlights certain free access articles pertaining to current events in the world.
The Economist presents the most thorough coverage of world events, providing scholarly, witty journalism for the informed citizen (of any country). Get it in your mailbox or on the web if you can't afford the print subscription fee. You won't be disappointed.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14: For years I have been trying to simulate a truly Italian espresso or cappuccino without success.  Several packages arrived from ... just before Christmas.  My son had sent a Briel Cadiz Espresso machine, two lovely Russian china cups and a case of Espressione Classic Espresso Pods.  It was the kindest, most wonderful Christmas present I can remember.  The espresso machine excels in quality and ease of use.  The espresso is exquisite.  Each time I prepare an espresso or cappuccino I experience my son's loving kindness and a small part of the many gifts of Italy.  Heaven on Earth.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14: For years I have been trying to simulate a truly Italian espresso or cappuccino without success.  Several packages arrived [...] just before Christmas.  My son had sent a Briel Cadiz Espresso machine, two lovely Russian china cups and a case of Espressione Classic Espresso Pods.  It was the kindest, most wonderful Christmas present I can remember.  The espresso machine excels in quality and ease of use.  The espresso is exquisite.  Each time I prepare an espresso or cappuccino I experience my son's loving kindness and a small part of the many gifts of Italy.  Heaven on Earth.

The finest experts in the US in economics, technology, sciences, and politics rate this magazine as the best in its class.  It is well-researched, balanced in point-of-view, and wittty.  Although it may be pricey, it is worth every penny.

The magazine is hands down the best ...by far. Eventhough, I am only 36 years old, I am really looking forward to retirement so that I can have the time to sit down with this magazine every week and read it from cover to cover. It is fantastic.
The writing is superb. All its competitors rely on verbatim quoting to tell a story or rely on smarmy puns and cliche's to carry the story. Not this magazine. They let the story or issue tell itself. No matter what the editor or authors bias is on the subject, they will always air the other side's point of view as well. The coverage is very wide and the articles hit the core without going on forever.

Some people complain that the magazine is dry.  I would offer that if you read it regularly it becomes more palatable over time (remember when differential equations were hard?).  More importantly it will give you insights and depth into the world that Time and Newsweek cant in there "News for Dummies" incarnation.  Reading the Economist is an investment in yourself and will improve your understanding of the world and you're thinking process as well.  The magazine authors are truly gifted and superlatively smart and witty to boot.  Needless to say I like this magazine (sic even better then Juggs).

Simply put, The Economist is the best news magazine available. It provides excellent coverage of international and economic affairs, and its "Leaders" which provide insight into major events of the day, including the war on terrorism, are exceptional. There are special reports, extended reporting on a single topic, in at least two issues every month.
Delving into such serious topics as war, finance and politics, one would expect The Economist to be very dry reading. Far from it. The magazine's jounalists (who are never credited with a byline) are the best news writers I have ever read. It is intelligent, witty and informative reading. If you're sick of Time and Newsweek, and are looking for something with greater depth, The Economist is the way to go.

column6: El Paso Chile Viva Fajitas Gourmet Food Gift Set
column14: Got this kit as a gift and I love it!  I am a pepper head and the Hell fire & damnation sauce is excellent!  The review says the pan makes enough for 1 fajita, That's ONE BIG fajita!!!  We cooked Plenty enough for 4 and only used 1/4 of the yummy smoky delicious marinade.  The pan is also great for eggs over the campfire!

I am a big fan of The Economist Magazine.
It represents the most classifical views of politics, economics, trades; it promotes free economy with proper govermental influence, free trade, democracy, social development, etc...
If you are interested in world politics, economy, if you want to understand more about other cultures, subscribe this magazine and you will find every article deserves its attention.
I save every issue since my first subscription.
I promist you will love it.

There are so many reasons to love the Economist, every week you get a great overview of the world. First off the writing is great, the stories are easy to read but don't treat you like a child. Unlike other weekly news magazines the Economist covers every corner of the globe in detail, so you can find an article about South America or Africa (and not just when a war is starting). Of course they also offer articles on business, but unlike other publications they avoid all of the silly hype and focus on the facts. Even the book reviews and obituaries are always made interesting to read! While you may not always agree on the viewpoint presented in the Economist, it is always a point of view worth thinking about. While you may not get rich from reading this publication, it will make you wiser. It's the perfect gift for the person who likes to think and explore the world from their living room.

column13: Best news and analysis, worldwide coverage, int'l viewpoint
column14:
The Economist is simply the finest magazine I have encountered. 11 sections with 5-10 full page articles each: Leaders, Europe, Britian, International, United States, The Americas, Asia, Business, Finance & Economics, Science & Technology, and Books & Arts.
Makes Newsweek, Time, US News look like People. Encompasses many of the macro business and economic issues of Business Week or Forbes and the technology topics of Red Herring.
Don't expect cute pictures and regurgitated news, but rather in-depth analysis and blunt but supported opinions. (...)

The Economist magazine is simply the best magazine I have found.  This magazine balances providing in-depth treatment while at the same time not becoming an academic tome.  After reading this magazine, you will realize Time, Newsweek, etc. are merely pop-culture rags.  I cannot recommend highly enough.
in the post-semptember era i tried hard to find a non bias magazine.ECONOMIST is the only one.I storngly reccomend it to readers who want to be informed preciesly and in time.

For a weekly magazine, The Economist packs in an enormous ammount of information, allowing it to be one of the most timely and accurate publications out there. Based in the UK, The Economist looks at the whole world, leaving no reagion untouched. There's a great deal of coverage of the US, but that's to be expected, considering the size of the US economy and the effect it has on the world.
The Economist is a refreshingly honest publication for those of us who don't necessarily subcribe to the notion that the American media is always objective.  The Economist is.

One of the best magazines with worldwide news coverage. Full of information on International economies, livlihoods, developments, politics, and issues pertinent to those international locations. Don't let the name of this magazine full you. Although there is a general overtone, it is very informative in many areas. With this magazine arriving weekly, I have difficulty getting through each one before the next arrives.
A great value!

This may be the most difficult review I ever write, for what can be said about this publication that anyone who reads these words does not already know? The title suggests news of interest only to accountants and bankers, so the insightful views of world affairs found in every issue go unappreciated by all but few.
A shame, for this is truly a great magazine.
What the Times is to daily news, what the New Yorker is to culture, that is what the Economist is to international affairs, business, and politics. Published in London, the Economist is free from the subtle corruption ever present in American corporate-sponsored magazines, providing a truly objective view of U.S. policy each and every week. (I can not speak for British readers, but they seem just as objective when discussing European affairs).
Put down the advertisement-rich and content-free magazines you force yourself to read. Get the magazine that sustained Nelson Mandela in prison. Get accurate reporting and real insight into the world you live in. GET THE ECONOMIST.

As an ultra-demanding reader with a dearth of time, I was ecstatic to find this magazine. The Economist introduced me to the subject of globalization in 1998, and I've been hooked ever since. This is my guidebook to informed living on planet Earth.
The Economist is not a finance periodical... it is well-nigh a -book- of analysis, completely current, spoken with one editorial voice, the voice of reason, common sense, and good humor. The name 'Economist' represents this weekly's founder's heartfelt belief that human value is a worthy cause, that everything can be expressed in terms of a holism of human values, and that every single significant event -should- be given this measurement. Every world happening has meaning to the economy of human life. Good and bad are real... no moral relativism here.
You can throw out your copy of Time, Newsweek, and the New York Times (including Sunday and the magazine). Compared to the Economist, all other U.S. periodicals (unfortunately) are nothing but a pose--and I'm a red-blooded American, raised in South Dakota... trust me, the Economist is a magazine everyman can approach and know.
News doesn't have to be a duty... this magazine makes it a delight. Save yourself some money and a heap of time, and gain your citizenship in the world. A+ publication!

column13: Best magazine for economics and politics
column14: I was first introduced to The Economist in my last few years of High School, my teacher assigned it as recommended reading for my Econ classes. Boy did it help! I have yet to find a more objective and analytical magazine on politics and economics. Whereas Time has always had a huge bias towards America and America's allies, the Economist (being British) has always been more objective and is straightforward and witty. It should be noted that this magazine is not for somebody who wants a quick summary of last week's news. This is for the reader who wants to get the details, and intensive analysis of economic and political issues. Although I've said above that the Economist is un-biased, I must admit that there is a definite Right-wing slant to most of its articles, but as far as I'm concerned, it's still more objective than Time, Newsweek and CNN.

column13: The Best News Magazine in the English Language
column14: While Time and Newsweek have become vapid picture books, the Economist has remained the reference standard for a weekly news magazine.  Simply the best...

column13: The Economist provides excellent international perspective
column14: I very much enjoy The Economist. I like its international focus, seemingly objective perspective and deep content. There is a huge amount of information to consume. The magazine is very text heavy-- if you are the type of reader who likes lots of pictures, this is not the periodical for you. However, if you like an in-depth international perspective on business, economics and politics then the Economist can provide great learning.

I've been an avid reader of the Economist for more than 6 years. If there is a better English-language newspaper on this planet, I've yet to discover it. The Leaders section contains an analysis of international news offering THE best synthesis of the week's major world events. The regional coverage is also outstanding. As a student of Southeast Asia, I immediately turn to the section covering Asia for the latest issues affecting the region. Then I read the Leaders, after which I read the Science and Technology section. Did I mention the excellent book reviews? They also publish timely special reports throughout the year as part of the magazine. Last month (September '01) they included an essential piece on globalization.

And if all that weren't enough, the Enonomist cover art is incredible! Subscribe now, you will not be disappointed.

column13: If you can only read one magazine a week...
column14: I find this is the best single source of news, with the added benefits that (1) it is more intellectual that the typical news rag like Time or Newsweek and (2) being from the UK it has a non-US slant on issues that you can't find in the US.  Admittedly a bit of British snobbery and resentment of US wealth creeps into the editorials, but the world view of this publication is very valuable.

If you want a single weekly to keep you up to speed with what's going on in the world, and \\"Time\\" or \\"Newsweek\\" leaves you feeling hungry for fresher ideas and less facile analysis, get \\"The Economist\\".  If you're like me, you won't have time to read every issue cover to cover, but you'll wish you did.  Informed, concise, and witty writing.
Adam Smith would have subscribed to this!

In today's jingoistic mainstream media environment - the economist is probably the only sane magazine.
The world news is 'real' world news and not some tattered bits
of irrelevent and highly subjective information doled out by the likes of Time et. al.
The editorials are at best insightful and at worst opinions that
you don't agree with - but never pedantic or pedestrian.
For someone who wants a real word view in the US - this is the best magazine out there.
Do your mind a favor- read the economist.

The quality of the analysis supercedes any other magazine.  It is refreshing to get such quality writing about diverse topics - international, business, political,and economic topics are all explored at length.

column6: Espressione Classic Coffee Pods, Box of 150
column14:
I purchased the LUNA by Espressione wall mount pump espresso machine which is designed for use with the ESE pods. The machine had two pods to test in the box and I'm tried them.
The coffee was rich, had a great aroma and sensational taste.
I ordered the 100% Arabica from amazon and am extremely happy with this coffee. 150 came in the box and I need to order again!

column6: Celestial Seasonings - Herbal Tea Caffeine Free True Blueberry
column14:
The Amor Belhom Duo are likely the only musicians to relocate from France to Tuscon, Arizona. Not that there's anything wrong with that. In Tuscon, they've hooked up with Joey Burns and John Convertino (the braintrust of the amazing Calexico), both of whom guest on Wavelab Performance. There is much about this album that reminds of the desert southwest sound perfected by Calexico, and yet there sneaks in a hint of Euro-ness that makes their sound unique. The guitars can offer fuzztones and feedback while the drums pound frenetically, and yet there isn't the sense that the music is directionless. The vocals are spare and the lyrics won't likely win any poetry contests, but in this context, they work. This may not be the kind of music that stays in the cd player for weeks on end, but it is a refreshing change of pace.
And if nothing else, it hints at what may come from the forthcoming formal Calexico/Amor Belhom Duo collaboration entitled "Tete A Tete". That should be one interesting release.

Being  a  Breyer  collecter  almost  all  of  my  life,  I  would  like  to  say  that  this  toy  is  great!  It  is  so  unique  in  every  way  and  it  is  the  perfect  mold  for  a  show  horse!  This  toy  is  not   only  fun  to  play  with,  but  it  is  also  very  durable  and  strong.   I  think  that  this  toy  is  educational  for  the  horse-lover's  mind.   I  shows  us  what  a  certin  kind  of  horse  would  look  like  without   them  having  to  buy  one.

This model is beautiful.  each model is hand painted, and looks unique.  these breyer models are hich quality and worth the money, but since there are some very weak parts of the model (like legs and tail) you have to be  careful.  Don't get it wrong, these are pretty strong.  They are not  exactly fragile or anything.... but overall pretty durable.  It is also  totally educational.  The box comes with the name of the breed of horse,  (in this case Bay Pinto) and its realistic features really help you learn  about that particular breed and what it looks like.  The thing i love about  this model and all other breyer models is the close resemblance to the real  thing.  These are not cheesy barbie horses with cheap plastic and  eyelashes...  This could hardly be called a toy.  It is something that  adults could collect, and put around the house as decoration.  Great for  all ages!

column13: don't have it yet..but  will soon
column14: As a person who has collected Breyers all my life, I can see the changes that Breyer has made with the horses that are sculptered. They look more realistic, and very detailed. I will always  collect them, all though I do have real horse of my own, Breyers make great gifts for kids and  grownups who live in the city or cannot afford a horse.
This Breyer horse is wonderful. She is beautiful and realistic. I also won a first place in a model horse show with her. But be careful- Breyer horses can easily be broken.
